subject: GBST (GBT AT) received 2 further non-binding indicative proposals

PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: CIMIC (CIM AT) UGL unit awarded AUD 630mln contract extension, WTI fell nearly 5% and Fast Retailing (9983 JT) June same store sales rose 27.3%
content:
AUSTRALIA

Australian Unity Office Fund (AOF AT) - Charter Hall (CHC AT) and Abacus Property (ABP AT) improve offer for Australian Unity Office Fund. (Newswires)

CIMIC (CIM AT) - Co. UGL unit awarded AUD 630mln contract extension for Sydney trains. (Newswires)

Mirvac (MGR AT) - Co. announced successful completion of security purchase plan. (Newswires)

Nufarm (NUF AT) - Co. said to have multiple parties interested although no formal approach has been made. (Newswires)

Vocus (VOC AT) - Co. affirms underlying EBITDA AUD 350mln-370mln. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Co. will separate Endeavour Group following merger of Endeavour Drinks and ALH. (Newswires)

Financials - CBA cut Standard Variable Rate on home loans by 19-25bps, ANZ cut variable mortgage rates by 25bps, NAB are to reduce their variable rate on home loans by 19bps and Westpac will lower variable interest rates for owner occupiers by 20bps and for interest only investors by 30bps. In related news, NAB CEO says it is becoming practically impossible for banks to offset drag from falling interest rates on loans by cutting returns offered to depositors. (Newswires/SMH)

Energy - WTI crude futures fell nearly 5% to below USD 57.00/bbl. (Newswires)

 

 

JAPAN

ABC-MART (2670 JT) - Co. June same store sales rose 5.5% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Fast Retailing (9983 JT) - Co. June same store sales rose 27.3% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Line (3938 JT) - Co. has been asked to clarify is pricing by the Japan Consumer Agency. (Newswires)

Mazda (7261 JT) - Co. June North America sales fell 15.1% Y/Y to 22.8k units. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JT) - Co. US June sales rose 10.5% Y/Y to 12.3k units. (Newswires)

Nomura Research Institute (4307 JT) - Co. may report Q1 oper. profit rose 17% Y/Y to JPY 18bln. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. is to launch a fund with Daiwa Securities Group (8601 JT) with a value of over JPY 20bln targeting investments in promising tech startups. (Nikkei)

Subaru (7270 JT) - Subaru America June sales rose 2.8% Y/Y to 61.5k units. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. June North America sales rose 2% Y/Y to 64.2k units. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. Galaxy S10 sales are reportedly 12% higher than its predecessor. (Yonhap)

Samsung Life Insurance (032830 KS) - Co. will sell 3.6% stake in DGB Financial (139130 KS). (Newswires)

Steel Makers - US Commerce Department is to impose duties of as much as 456% on certain steel produced in South Korea or Taiwan and further processed in Vietnam. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan is said to consider additional export restrictions on South Korea. (Newswires)

Australian CBA Composite PMI (Jun F) 52.5 (Prev. 53.1)

US President Trump says he intends to nominate Christopher Waller who is Executive VP and Director of Research at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, Missouri for the Fed board, while he also intends to nominate Judy Shelton

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

RBA Governor Lowe said the two cuts in interest rates the Board delivered recently will make an important contribution to putting us on a better path and winding back spare capacity, while he added that the board is prepared to adjust interest rates again if needed to get us closer to full employment and achieve the inflation target. Furthermore, Lowe stated that Australia's terms of trade have risen again largely due to higher iron ore prices, investment in the resources sector is also expected to increase over the next few years and that they are expecting a solid upswing in the resources sector which will help the overall economy. (Newswires)

New Zealand Dairy Prices Changes -0.4% (Prev. -3.8%) and Whole Milk Powder Price Change 0.0% (Prev. -4.3%). (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

BoE's Carney said that he sees Q2 growth considerably weaker and that in some jurisdictions, the impact of uncertainty may warrant a near-term policy response as insurance in order to maintain the expansion. Carney also commented that a tight UK labour market, inflation at target, prospect of greater clarity around Brexit argues for focus on medium-term inflation dynamics, while he also noted that a global trade war and no-deal Brexit remain growing possibilities but not certainties and that in the event Brexit progresses smoothly, limited and gradual rate rises would still be needed. (Newswires)

German Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen was proposed as President of the European Commission, while Belgian PM Charles Michel was named as President of the European council and IMF's Lagarde was nominated as ECB President. Furthermore, EU Council President Tusk said it is our intention to have a socialist President of the EU Parliament for the first term and a centre-right for the second, while he also commented that Von Der Leyen is to pick Timmermans and Vestager as Deputy Heads of the Commission. (Newswires)

ECB’s Lane suggested it depends what happens regarding time estimation on negative rates as the world is quite uncertain, while Lane added we have a baseline forecast which remains optimistic for Europe but recognise there are downside risks. (Newswires)

ECB policymakers reportedly see no need to rush into a rate cut in July, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Construction PMI (Jun) 43.1 vs. Exp. 49.3 (Prev. 48.6). (Newswires)

 

FX

SNB’s Zurbruegg stated that negative interest rates and a readiness to intervene are the key to reducing attractiveness of the CHF. Zurbruegg added there is flexibility and room to move on core instrument, while we are convinced they can be used and will continue to do so. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

API Weekly Crude Inventories -5mln vs. Exp. -3.0mln (Prev. -7.6mln). (Newswires)

Russia approved the OPEC+ output deal extension for nine-months, while OPEC+ have agreed on a "Charter of Cooperation" to formalize their relationship pending approval from individual governments. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said Russia will fully comply with OPEC+ output pact and supports using the 2010-2014 period for their oil reserve metrics, while Novak sees oil demand growth for 2019 at 1.1mln-1.2mln BPD and added that the current oil price is a good result. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

Foreign ministers from Germany, France, UK, and EU High Representative said they are extremely concerned by Iran exceeding uranium limits, while Iran Foreign Minister Zarif reiterated that Iran will stick to the nuclear pact as long as the Europeans stick to their economic commitments. (Newswires)

Russian Foreign Ministry said Moscow is concerned by the escalation of the Israeli strikes on Syria. (RIA)

 

GLOBAL NEWS

US VP Pence cancelled an event in New Hampshire on Tuesday saying there is an emergency and he is being called back to the White House, although the VP's office said it was not cancelled for an emergency and rather a "diversion" back to Washington DC, while a White House official said the VP Pence meeting was not related to health nor related to national security. (Newswires/Fox/CBS)

Russian President Putin pulled out of an event and met with his Defence Minister following a submersible accident in Russian waters, while an inquiry was ordered into the accident with the submarine. (Tass) 

 

US

Fed's Mester (Non-Voter, Hawk) said cutting rates now could reinforce negative sentiment and encourage financial imbalances, while she added that the effect of already imposed tariffs are "relatively modest". Mester also commented that it is too early to determine whether the economy is moving to weak-growth scenario and that prefers to get more data in before considering a change to policy. (Newswires)

White House Trade Advisor Navarro said we are moving in a very good direction in the US-China trade talks. Navarro also commented that the Fed hiked rates too fast and tightened too soon, while he added that hopefully the Fed will the right thing and lower rates. (CNBC) 

 

MARKET RECAP

L3Harris technologies (LHX) pared back Monday’s losses after being named a top pick at Jefferies. Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) moved closer to completing their merger after reaching a divesture agreement with Dish (DISH). Western Digital (WDC) and Ingersoll-Rand (IR) underperformed following downgrades at Benchmark and Jefferies respectively. Electronic Arts (EA) benefitted from a PT rise at BMO. Life insurers tumbled after JPMorgan released a negative note on the sector (AIG, PRU, BHF). Delta Air Lines (DAL) opened on the front foot on the back of strong June traffic reporting. Energy was a laggard given the sell off in crude. UBS downgraded Nordstrom (JWN) based on a negative outlook, seeing the stock and competitors Kohl’s (KSS), Macy’s (M), and Gap (GPS) follow suit. Perrigo (PRGO) rallied after it raised its FY19 EPS view. S&P 500 0.3% AT 2973, NASDAQ-100 0.4% AT 7800, DOW JONES 0.3% AT 26788.

The Treasury curve bull-steepened after the Trump focused on the Eurozone as its next adversary in the trade wars. Once again, the T-Note took cues from EGBs, which have seen yields fall to fresh lows, with traders chewing the fat over the weak economic backdrop, and the dovish comments from a noted hawk (ECB's Knot) on Monday. In afternoon trade, IMF’s Lagarde emerged as the front-runner for the ECB top job, which added a bid in the fixed income space, as the candidate is viewed as less hawkish than other names that were in the frame. A bout of risk-off in the afternoon also sent the T-Note to HOD, after geopolitical tensions (around the same time, it was announced that US VP Pence had cancelled an appearance, the Russian President met his defence minister, while there were also reports that the EU Security Committee was meeting, leading to speculation that we could be on the cusp of some sort of geopolitical escalation; however, a White House official deflated the panic, stating that there was no national security angle). The T-Note remained near highs at settlement. US T-note (U9) futures settled 14+ higher at 128-04+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 2nd July 2019: Post-G20 sugar high fades; oil slides despite OPEC+ deal
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

* SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, dollar down, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: US proposes fresh EU tariffs; Lagarde nominated for ECB top job; traders ‘sell the fact’ on OPEC+. 

* COMING UP: Data: Australian Building Approvals, Japanese, Chinese, EZ , UK and US Services PMI; US ADP, Factory Orders & ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI. Events: Riksbank Rate Decision. Speakers: Riksbank’s Ingves, Hansson, Floden & Ohlsson, BoE’s Cunliffe, Haldane & Broadbent and ECB’s de Galhau. Auctions: Japanese JPY 700bln 2049 & German EUR 4.0bln 2024

NOTE: DUE EARLIER MARKET CLOSURES, THE DESK WILL SHUT AT 1800 BST/1300 EDT ON WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY (ASIA SERVICE WILL RESUME AT 2200 BST/1700 EDT ON BOTH DAYS, AS PER NORMAL)

* MARKETS: On Monday, after gapping on the open to fresh record highs, the rise in the SPX was faded in thin conditions, while uncertainty still lingers on the stage of global trade. That optimism continued to be faded on Tuesday, although we managed to eke out some small gains later in the session. Traders continue to cite the lack of details, or even meaningful progress, with the G20 seen as only papering over existing gulfs; there is still no timetable for talks, and with both sides intransigent in their positions, it is difficult to see how a deal can be found, especially while the US has its sights on Europe next. Havens accordingly have been in demand, and yields were lower by 2-5.5bps across the curve. The USD is essentially flat, holding above the 200dma. 

* TRADE: As trade war escalation against China has been put on ice after the outcome of the G20, the USTR has turned his gaze to Europe, overnight publishing a list of USD 4bln of EU goods (which are in addition to the USD 21bln goods identified in April) to target in retaliation for the EU providing subsidies to Airbus. The WTO has already judged that the EU subsidies are a violation of international trade laws, and is expected to make a decision in the summer on the amount of countermeasures that the US can impose on the bloc. After the US opening bell, White House Trade Advisor Navarro told CNBC that the US/China talks were moving in a very good direction; on the Fed, he chimed with US President Trump, arguing that Fed hiked rates too quickly, and hopefully it will ‘do the right thing’ and lower rates.

* EU TOP JOBS: EU leaders have nominated IMF Chief Christine Lagarde to be the next ECB President. Some analysts have noted that the nomination of someone with a more political background may have been intentional, where the ECB has to navigate a variety of fiscal regimes in its policy decisions; some have also raised eyebrows at the prospect of having Lagarde and De Guindos (ECB VP) running the second most important central bank following careers in politics. Other top jobs chosen included Germany’s Ursula von der Leyen for Commission President, Belgium’s Charles Michel for Council President, and Spain’s Joseph Borrell for Foreign-Policy Chief. NOTE: lawmakers will still need to vote on the jobs positions.

* WTI (Q9) SETTLE USD 2.84 LOWER AT USD 56.25; BRENT (U9) SETTLE USD 2.66 LOWER AT USD 62.40. The crude complex suffered from considerable selling on what analysts attribute as a “sell the fact” scenario after OPEC+ extended cuts as expected. As the data docket again highlights the fragile nature of global growth, and as the US refocuses its trade crosshairs onto Europe, the demand side of the equation is back in focus, allowing traders to book some profits. UBS said that while risks and uncertainties remain, OPEC continues to demonstrate the ability and the willingness to manage softening demand, and UBS strategists continue to believe supply-side risks that should push oil higher; indeed the bank argues that these risks are not receiving sufficient attention; although other analysts have highlighted the de-bottlenecking of the Permian Basin and more supply out of Canada as bearish supply factors to consider in H2 2019. The near-term volatility risk to energy markets is the US energy inventory reports, kicking off with the API reporting after the bell, followed by the official EIA data on Wednesday. Current inventory expectations see draws across the board, with crude at -3mln bbls, gasoline stocks at -2.2mln bbls, and distillates at -1mln bbls.

* ECB: ECB policymakers reportedly see no need to rush into a rate cut in July, according to sources. Governing Council may tweak language at upcoming meeting to hint at the potential for more stimulus ahead.

* RBA: Cut its Cash Rate by 25bps to a fresh record low of 1.00% – the first back-to-back rate cut since 2012, after rates were left unchanged for three years. HSBC’s RBA watcher Paul Bloxham said the sharpness of the adjustment suggests bigger growth fears, despite the statement's attempts to put the cut in a positive light. The tweaks to the statement were small: analysts reason that the central bank is concerned about global growth in the context of 'trade and technology' disputes ('technology' was added); the central bank's assessment of the domestic economy was unchanged, and it reiterated its view that the labour market is strong (though this is still expected to be the key driver of RBA moves); inflation is still seen as subdued. It did, however, upgrade its guidance on the housing market (now sees tentative signs of stabilisation). RBC thinks the RBA watered down its previous explicit easing bias in favour of a more data dependant approach, and that despite less strident forward guidance, the door still remains open to further cuts ahead, with the onus now on Q3 data needing to improve in order for the central bank to hold rates steady at 1%. OIS were pricing a 67% chance of a further rate cut this year in wake of today’s rate decision. In his post-meeting press conference, Governor Lowe then signalled that the Central Bank will likely stand pat in the coming months to examine the impact of the back-to-back cuts and the proposed AUD 110bln tax cut package, which looks almost certain to pass.

* BOE’S CARNEY: The BOE governor warned on Q2 growth, stating that it will be “considerably weaker”. Carney said that a global trade war and no-deal Brexit remain as growing possibilities, not certainties, and in the event that Brexit progresses smoothly, limited and gradual rate rises would still be needed (this is a repeat of current BOE guidance). Carney also said that he was noticing an increasing inconsistency between markets projections and the MPC's smooth Brexit assumptions. On the domestic economy, the Governor said the UK labour market was tight, inflation was at target, and the prospect of greater clarity around Brexit argues for focus on medium-term inflation dynamics. Carney, alluding to the Fed, said that in some jurisdictions the impact of uncertainty may warrant a near-term policy response as insurance in order to maintain the expansion.

* FED: Fed’s Mester (non-voter, hawk) said that cutting rates now could reinforce negative sentiment and encourage financial imbalances, and in regard to trade concerns said that the effect of already imposed tariffs are "relatively modest". Mester expressed she wanted to see more data before considering a change to policy (a hawkish position given the dovish tilt of most of its members).

* BREXIT/UK DATA: Bookies’ underdog Jeremy Hunt pledged that he would not suspend parliament in order to push through a no deal Brexit, contrasting him with the favourite Boris Johnson. The declaration comes amid a poll which showed 59% of Conservative Party members want the new UK PM to be ready to leave the EU with no deal if negotiations with the EU fail. UK data continues to slump after the stockpiling seen ahead of the first end-March end date, with a grim construction PMI seeing all major sub-components ease, while a survey of small businesses suggested that firms were shelving capex plans amid the Brexit uncertainty.

* NZ QSBO: Overnight, the latest NZIER Quarterly Survey of Business Opinion (QSBO) showed business confidence fell to its lowest level since March 2009, with a net 31% of businesses expecting a deterioration in general economic conditions over the coming months. Adding to the negative news was a further decline in firms’ own trading activity, with a net 4% of businesses reporting reduced demand in the June quarter. A net 4% of businesses also expect demand to fall in the next quarter – the weakest level since June 2009. These measures suggest a softening in annual GDP growth to below 2 percent over the second half of 2019, NZIER said.

*S&P 500 0.3% AT 2973, NASDAQ-100 0.4% AT 7800, DOW JONES 0.3% AT 26788. SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  0.3%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  0.9%, S&P 500 Energy  -1.7%, S&P 500 Financials  -0.2%, S&P 500 Health Care  0.4%, S&P 500 Industrials  -0.1%, S&P 500 Information Technology  0.3%, S&P 500 Materials  -0.1%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  1.1%, S&P 500 Utilities  1.3%

* STOCKS: L3Harris technologies (LHX) pared back Monday’s losses after being named a top pick at Jefferies. Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) moved closer to completing their merger after reaching a divesture agreement with Dish (DISH). Western Digital (WDC) and Ingersoll-Rand (IR) underperformed following downgrades at Benchmark and Jefferies respectively. Electronic Arts (EA) benefitted from a PT rise at BMO. Life insurers tumbled after JPMorgan released a negative note on the sector (AIG, PRU, BHF). Delta Air Lines (DAL) opened on the front foot on the back of strong June traffic reporting. Energy was a laggard given the sell off in crude. UBS downgraded Nordstrom (JWN) based on a negative outlook, seeing the stock and competitors Kohl’s (KSS), Macy’s (M), and Gap (GPS) follow suit. Perrigo (PRGO) rallied after it raised its FY19 EPS view.

* US T-NOTE (U9) FUTURES SETTLE 14+ HIGHER AT 128-04+: The Treasury curve bull-steepened after the Trump focused on the Eurozone as its next adversary in the trade wars. Once again, the T-Note took cues from EGBs, which have seen yields fall to fresh lows, with traders chewing the fat over the weak economic backdrop, and the dovish comments from a noted hawk (ECB's Knot) on Monday. In afternoon trade, IMF’s Lagarde emerged as the front-runner for the ECB top job, which added a bid in the fixed income space, as the candidate is viewed as less hawkish than other names that were in the frame. A bout of risk-off in the afternoon also sent the T-Note to HOD, after geopolitical tensions (around the same time, it was announced that US VP Pence had cancelled an appearance, the Russian President met his defence minister, while there were also reports that the EU Security Committee was meeting, leading to speculation that we could be on the cusp of some sort of geopolitical escalation; however, a White House official deflated the panic, stating that there was no national security angle). The T-Note remained near highs at settlement.

* FX WRAP: The Buck has been holding losses, though DXY has kept its head above the 200dma mark, as the dollar gives back some of Monday’s post-G20 gains. The EUR has largely been pinned to 1.13. Havens JPY, CHF and XAU advanced during afternoon risk off, with XAU retaking USD 1400, and JPY relinquished 108. CAD was up despite falling oil prices. GBP is basing around 1.26 after weak construction PMI, cautious BOE comments, and USD strength. AUD faced short covering after the RBA, though was supported by higher iron ore, though still finds 0.70 a challenge to usurp. EMFX was higher against the buck, but not BRL, which was weaker after IP fell, while the BCB chief warned of an interruption in the country’s recovery. TRY also gave back gains seen on Monday after improved geopolitical climate between Turkey and US, although Wednesday’s inflation data will now provide the next catalyst.

* USD: The buck gave back some of the post G20 gains, though DXY is keeping its head above its 200dma (around 96.65) heading into APAC trade. It is worth keeping an eye on how the USD reacts to stock rallies, with some desks arguing that unhedged inflows (into stocks) could be another factor providing support for the buck. The data slate now comes into focus (ADP/NFP) and crucially, how the Fed judges the evolution of risks after a favourable G20 outcome on trade between US/China.

* HAVENS: Havens were bid amid a concoction of risk-off in afternoon trade, seeing JPY fall sub-108, EURCHF to 1.1125, XAU rise above USD 1400, while T-Notes were rallying to session highs. There was some unwind after it emerged that there was no national security threat being cited for the reason VP Pence was to meet US President Trump.

* EUR: Heavy option expiries kept EUR actioned pinned to 1.13, and after the NY cut was out of the way, there was downside; however, 1.13 continues to draw action. The single currency remained supported despite major yields falling to fresh lows; desks are suggesting keeping an eye on the yield situation – while the French 10-year has gone negative, and the Bund continues to print fresh record lows in negative territory (traders attempting to front-run any potential ECB QE announcement in the months ahead?), some desks reason, the BTP could be supported by its own positive yielding 10-year, a trend worth watching given that the Bund/BTP spread can exert influence on the EUR itself; perhaps not enough to shake-off the impasse over the top EU jobs, SocGen argues, but maybe enough to defend the bottom of the recent EURUSD range. 

* AUD: Short covering after the RBA, a weaker USD, and rising iron ore prices support the Aussie, though it finds the air above 0.70 thin.  It appears certain the government will be able to push through tax cuts this week, and the SMH newspaper reporting that there are no roadblocks to passage, just bumps in the road that need to smoothed-out. The Centre-Alliance has the two votes the LNP needs for 38 to make law (LNP already has 36 reliable votes in the new senate. Labor has made it likely that there will be a deal with the CA by signalling that it will wave through the plan if their amendments fail, UBS explains, “so this massively reduces the bargaining power of the CA. Depending on who you ask, the first stage of the plan (which will be implemented immediately) will have the impact of around 50bps of rate cuts.”

* GBP: Sterling slumps despite USD weakness, with BOE Governor Carney warning on Q2 data. That followed a grim construction PMI, which again highlights the challenge the UK economy is facing as the Brexit stockpiling dissipates from the data. 

* NZD: The Q2 Quarterly Survey of Business Opinion was the weakest since 2009, and hints at softer growth in H2.

* TRY: Was lower on Monday, despite signs that geopolitical tensions between Turkey and the US have eased; the fate of the rally may depend on inflation data released Wednesday, which is expected to ease to just above 16.0% in June; SocGen says a bond-friendly inflation print could continue to support flows in the TRY.

  • TRY: Was lower on Monday, despite signs that geopolitical tensions between Turkey and the US have eased; the fate of the rally may depend on inflation data released Wednesday, which is expected to ease to just above 16.0% in June; SocGen says a bond-friendly inflation print could continue to support flows in the TRY.

subject: US T-Note futures (U9) settled 14+ higher at 128-04+
analysis_details: The Treasury curve bull-steepened after the Trump focused on the Eurozone as its next adversary in the trade wars. Once again, the T-Note took cues from EGBs, which have seen yields fall to fresh lows, with traders chewing the fat over the weak economic backdrop, and the dovish comments from a noted hawk (ECB's Knot) on Monday. In afternoon trade, IMF’s Lagarde emerged as the front-runner for the ECB top job, which added a bid in the fixed income space, as the candidate is viewed as less hawkish than other names that were in the frame. A bout of risk-off in the afternoon also sent the T-Note to HOD, after geopolitical tensions (around the same time, it was announced that US VP Pence had cancelled an appearance, the Russian President met his defence minister, while there were also reports that the EU Security Committee was meeting, leading to speculation that we could be on the cusp of some sort of geopolitical escalation; however, a White House official deflated the panic, stating that there was no national security angle). The T-Note remained near highs at settlement.

subject: WTI futures (Q9) settle USD 2.84 lower at USD 56.25/bbl; Brent futures (U9) settle USD 2.66 lower at USD 62.40/bbl
analysis_details: The crude complex suffered from considerable selling on what analysts attribute as a “sell the fact” scenario after OPEC+ extended cuts as expected. As the data docket again highlights the fragile nature of global growth, and as the US refocuses its trade crosshairs onto Europe, the demand side of the equation is back in focus, allowing traders to book some profits. UBS said that while risks and uncertainties remain, OPEC continues to demonstrate the ability and the willingness to manage softening demand, and UBS strategists continue to believe supply-side risks that should push oil higher; indeed the bank argues that these risks are not receiving sufficient attention; although other analysts have highlighted the de-bottlenecking of the Permian Basin and more supply out of Canada as bearish supply factors to consider in H2 2019. The near-term volatility risk to energy markets is the US energy inventory reports, kicking off with the API reporting after the bell, followed by the official EIA data on Wednesday. Current inventory expectations see draws across the board, with crude at -3mln bbls, gasoline stocks at -2.2mln bbls, and distillates at -1mln bbls.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Aussie outperforms, as RBA’s Lowe signals 1% OCR floor (for now)
content:
AUD/NZD

The Aussie has extended its relatively impressive recovery and touched psychological marks vs its US and Antipodean peers in wake of remarks from RBA’s Lowe following the latest ¼ point rate cut that suggest a time out after 50 bp cumulative easing since June (ie consecutive reductions in the OCR to a new 1% record low). Aud/Usd has drifted back from 0.7000, but remains well off the 0.6958 overnight trough and Aud/Nzd reached 1.0500 from 1.0434 at one stage as the Kiwi acknowledges the latest GDT auction results (dairy and WMP prices both firmer than previous) and pares some losses against the Greenback within a 0.6657-80 range. Note, the Nzd was also undermined by a downbeat NZIER business survey overnight showing a drop in morale and ASB predicting ½ point more RBNZ easing.

JPY/SEK

The next best G10s on renewed safe-haven demand and relatively hawkish policy vibes respectively, as the Yen rebounds towards 108.00 vs the Dollar and the Swedish Krona revisits recent highs through 10.5400 against the Euro ahead of Wednesday’s Riksbank policy meeting that is expected to confirm that tightening is still on the agenda, albeit perhaps pushed back further again – see the headline feed and Research Suite for our preview.

GBP

Sterling was already on the rocks after a shocking UK construction PMI, but the 1.2600 Cable break and spike to 0.8968 in Eur/Gbp came in wake of comments from BoE’s Carney about considerably weak Q2 GDP and heightened downside economic risks due to global trade tensions. From a technical perspective, the Pound may glean some support ahead of 1.2550 via a 1.2568 Fib and 0.9000 at the 0.8992 late June high.

EUR/CAD

Both mildly firmer vs the Buck, albeit choppy as the DXY holds a tight line between 96.879-624 and close to the 200 DMA (circa 96.650) that could be pivotal from a chart standpoint on a closing basis. Eur/Usd reversed early weakness down to around 1.1275 on the back of dismal German retail sales and pessimistic 2019 updates from the DIHK and VDMA, especially on the export front as ECB sources suggested July may be too soon for a rate cut, not long after a rise in money market expectations for a 10 bp ease next month. However, the headline pair only reached 1.1320 before waning amidst a further collapse in Eurozone/global bond yields and with 1 bn option expiries acting like a magnet into the NY cut (from 1.1295-1.1300). Meanwhile, the Loonie held up relatively well in the face of retreating oil prices (OPEC 9 month extension at prior output cut levels well and truly priced in it seems) with the aid of a slightly firmer Canadian manufacturing PMI and shrugging off typically hawkish-leaning comments from Fed’s Mester (who is a non-voter to be fair). Usd/Cad stuck within 1.3108-38 trading parameters.

CHF

The Franc did not benefit from dwindling post-G20 risk appetite to the same degree as the Yen, and a timely reminder from SNB’s Zurbruegg about the need to maintain NIRP and a readiness to intervene given the Swiss currency’s traditional allure may have been heeded. Usd/Chf meandered between 0.9865-88 and Eur/Chf straddled 1.1150 as a result.

Elsewhere, CEO Tim Cook said in an NBC interview that the claims in the WSJ that Chief Designer Jony Ive left due to Cook’s lack of interest in design were “absurd”. NASDAQ 100

Elsewhere, Motherboard reports that Amazon worked alongside US law enforcement on a package theft sting operation which ultimately didn’t lead to any arrests.
  • Facebook (FB) (Consumer Discretionary/Interactive Media & Services) – Facebook has been fined EUR 2bln by German regulators for violating German transparency law. Elsewhere, NY Governor Cuomo has requested the Department of Financial Services to probe FB over allegations that state-regulated advertisers are using the platform to discriminate against certain classes, particular in real estate.

Fritzsche believes the ruling is more likely to be positive for the deal, with concessions.
  • Western Digital (WDC) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) has been downgraded to Sell from Hold at Benchmark, where analyst Mark Miller believes short-term price increases will be overshadowed by an expected 50% fall in NAND output caused by the Yokaichi power outage.

JPMorgan analyst Andrea Teixeira expressed similar concerns.
  • Whirlpool (WHR) (Consumer Discretionary/Household Durables) has completed the USD 1.08bln sale of its Embraco unit to the Japanese co., Nidec.

  • Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Road & Rail), Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road & Rail) – Stifel analyst Scott Devitt raised his PT for Lyft to USD 76 from USD 70, Devitt is positive on Lyft’s position for extended rider growth momentum this year in addition to its innovation and strategic alignment in the sector, demonstrated by its Waymo acquisition. However, Devitt has initiated Uber with a Hold rating, citing “numerous competitors” with a “significantly long road to profitability”.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are largely unchanged this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] as sentiment slips from yesterday’s G20 inspired gains
  • US President Trump said a new round of trade talks with China have started and that he expects Chinese President Xi will move on some of the disputed issues
  • US Trade Representative Office proposed increased tariffs on EU products due to EU aircraft subsidies, in which it proposed adding more tariffs to USD 4.0bln of EU goods
  • Russia approves the OPEC+ output deal extension for nine-months, and the pact for an extension is to be signed soon., OPEC sources
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, Canadian Manufacturing PMI, OPEC+ Meeting, Fed's Mester & BoE’s Carney

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as the euphoria from the US-China trade truce began to wane and with the region looking ahead to this week’s key risk events. ASX 200 (U/C) was underpinned by strength in mining names and amid a widely anticipated back-to-back rate cut from the RBA, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) was choppy and largely reflected the price action in the domestic currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (U/C) were mixed with the mainland dampened after another liquidity drain by the PBoC, while Hong Kong outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend and amid declines in money market rates, with casino stocks among the biggest gainers following the strong growth in Macau gaming revenue. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued by the indecisive risk tone and after mixed results at the 10yr JGB auction failed to spur prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net drain of CNY 90bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8513 (Prev. 6.8716)

US President Trump said a new round of trade talks with China have started and that he expects Chinese President Xi will move on some of the disputed issues. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li reiterated that China will not resort to competitive devaluations and will protect IP rights even more strictly, as well as further ease ownership limits in more sectors. Premier Li added that China will maintain prudent monetary policy and no 'flood-like' stimulus, but will use RRR, targeted RRR and lower real interest rate to help reduce funding costs for small firms. (Newswires)

China's Premier Li states that China will significantly lower real financing costs for small firms, aiming for 1 percentage point cut this year. (Newswires)

US

US Trade Representative Office proposed increased tariffs on EU products due to EU aircraft subsidies, in which it proposed adding more tariffs to USD 4.0bln of EU goods. (Newswires)

US President Trump said Mexico tariffs are off the table and that the country is doing a good job. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson is considering proposals to reduce the size of the Cabinet after key backers urged him to slim down the government if he becomes PM. The Departments for Justice, Business, Culture, International Trade, Work and Pensions, Transport, and Brexit could all be abolished or merged with other departments. (Telegraph)

- Subsequently, these reports have been dismissed by sources close to Boris Johnson. (Twitter/Politics Home)

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI (Jun) 43.1 vs. Exp. 49.3 (Prev. 48.6)

- UK home-building PMI sub-component turns negative for first time in 17 months

- New orders dropped to the largest extent in just over 10-years, IHS's Moore

ECB’s Lane in the context of a time estimation on negative rates states that, it depends on what happens, as you know the world is quite uncertain, we have a baseline forecast which remains optimistic for Europe but we recognise there are downside risks., (Newswires)

ECB Policy Makers see no need to rush into a rate cut in July., sources. (Newswires)

DIHK cuts German 2019 export growth forecast to 1% vs. 2.5% in Autumn 2019, add that trade disputes and protectionism are affecting German Co's abroad

- German engineering orders -7% May, domestic orders -1% and foreign orders -9%., VDMA. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump said he had a great meeting with North Korea Leader Kim and looks forward to meeting him again soon, while he added that their teams will be meeting in the meantime to work out solutions to long-term and persistent problems. In related news, White House National Security adviser Bolton denied media reports the US may settle for a nuclear freeze by North Korea instead of full denuclearization. (Twitter/Newswires)

US President Trump suggested that Iran is playing with fire although he separately commented that hopefully the US will make a deal with Iran and that he would like to exit Afghanistan, but it is a tough position. (Newswires/Fox)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed and overall largely unchanged [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] as sentiment deteriorated overnight with the notable development being that the US Trade Representative Office has proposed increasing tariffs on EU products as a result of the aircraft subsidies; with a proposed USD 4.0bln of additional tariffs being added.  The tariffs would be on-top of the USD 21bln worth of tariffs announced by the USTR in April, with the products in question encompassing a vast range including whisky, iron tubes and cheese; a public hearing on these additions is scheduled for August 5th. Airbus (-0.9%) are afflicted on these additions as they are at the center of the European aircraft subsidies. Similarly, sectors are mixed with utilities and consumer staples outperforming on the day. In terms of this mornings notable movers, Adidas (-0.4%) opened lower after a downgrade at HSBC. Separately, but still within the Dax (-0.2%), Deutsche Bank (-0.7%) have slipped into negative territory as the broader index deteriorates on the back of negative comments from the VDMA this morning; however, the Co. did open around 1.1% higher on reports that they are considering lowering their capital buffer in order to fund the Co’s overhaul. Finally, Casino (+2.0%) are higher after selling 8 stores. 

FX

AUD/NZD - The Aussie has staged another strong rebound from fleeting overnight lows as bears quickly seized the opportunity to book profits in wake of the RBA’s decision to cut the OCR by another 25 bp, and other short positions were covered/squeezed on the accompanying statement suggesting no rush to ease again at the next policy meeting. Subsequently, comments from Governor Lowe appear to affirm a wait-and-see stance given back-to-back moves and Aud/Usd is inching closer to 0.7000 from 0.6958 lows, while Aud/Nzd has rebounded from sub-1.0450 towards 1.0500, with the Kiwi independently hampered by a further deterioration in NZIER business sentiment and ASB’s call for 2 more RNBZ rate reductions. Consequently, Nzd/Usd is hovering closer to the bottom of a 0.6657-80 range and eyeing the latest GDT auction next.

GBP/EUR - The Pound has tumbled to the base of the G10 pile on the back of June’s UK construction PMI that confounded expectations for a modest recovery and slumped even deeper into contraction at 43.1, much worse than the manufacturing miss on Monday. Moreover, components like housing and new orders were bleak, as the former fell below zero for the first time in 17 months and the latter weakened the most in over a decade. Cable is clinging to 1.2600 and Eur/Gbp is edging up towards 0.8960 as the single currency rebounds further from daily chart support vs the Dollar ahead of a Fib (circa 1.1277 and 1.1259 respectively) on ECB sourced reports downplaying July rate cut speculation. However, Eur/Usd faded around 1.1320 and could be drawn back towards decent option expiry interest between 1.1295-1.1300 (1 bn), especially after considerably weaker than forecast German retail sales data and some bleak numbers/outlooks from the likes of the DIHK and VDMA.

JPY - The Yen retains a relatively firm underlying bid on safe-haven grounds as the initial post-G20 euphoria dissipates and attention shifts back to the global slowdown and geopolitical factors, like the ongoing US-Iran spat. Hence, Usd/Jpy remains capped around 108.50 and the 30 DMA (108.55), but also confined on the downside at 108.00 given a generally firm Greenback as the DXY has bounced further from recent lows and back over the 200 DMA (96.690) into a loftier 96.624-879 band.

RBA lowered the Cash Rate by 25bps to a record low 1.00% as expected and stated that it cut rates to support employment growth, as well as provide greater confidence on inflation. RBA noted that the economy can sustain a lower rate of unemployment and that employment growth remains strong, while it added that the outlook for the global economy remains reasonable and that there are signs house prices are stabilizing in Sydney and Melbourne. (Newswires)

RBA Governor Lowe says the two cuts in interest rates the Board has delivered recently will make an important contribution to putting us on a better path and winding back spare capacity

- Given the circumstances, the Board is prepared to adjust interest rates again if needed to get us closer to full employment and achieve the inflation target

- Australia's terms of trade have risen again, largely due to higher iron ore prices. Investment in the resources sector is also expected to increase over the next few years, after having declined steadily for almost seven years - are expecting a solid upswing in the resources sector, which will help the overall economy

- The exchange rate has depreciated over the past couple of years and, on a trade-weighted basis, is at the bottom end of its range of recent times., helping support important parts of the economy.

- Are expecting stronger growth in household disposable income over the next couple of years, partly due to the expected implementation of the low and middle income tax offset

ANZ has cut variable mortgage rates by 25bps effective July 12 following the RBA's rate cut. (Newswires)

- CBA have cut their Standard Variable Rate home loans by 19-25bps, following the RBA rate decision

- NAB are to reduce their variable rate on home loans by 19bps as of July 12th 

FIXED

Gilts have forged more gains beyond the 131.00 handle and the equivalent 10 year yield is on the brink of 75 bp in wake of the BoE rate cutting kind of UK construction PMI that bodes badly for the big services survey on Wednesday, especially given the more pronounced contraction in manufacturing seen yesterday. The 10 year contract just topped out at 131.29 and was only briefly derailed in wake of 2024 DMO supply that seemed to encounter a degree of digestion, but was reasonably well received. Conversely, Bunds remain just shy of their fresh high in wake of ECB sources shying away from a July ease and with the Eurozone periphery outpacing the core, while US Treasuries are firmer and flatter in to Fed commentary and Empire State manufacturing.

COMMODITIES

The oil complex is somewhat subdued as the G20-driven positive sentiment waned. Brent (-0.4%) and WTI (-0.4%) have failed to find much support this morning on OPEC agreeing to extend the oil output cut by 9-months; with the OPEC+ meeting commencing today and the press conference expected at around 12:00 BST. In terms of recent commentary sources indicate that Russian Energy Minister Novak has given his support to the extension, with the deal to be signed soon. Nonetheless, markets will remain on guard for any dissent at today’s meeting from the non-OPEC members, with the joint verdict on an extension not expected until the OPEC+ press conference. From a technical perspective for WTI, PVM highlight that USD 59.07/bbl and USD 58.57/bbl are the two ‘pivot points’ to keep an eye on. Looking ahead, aside from the OPEC+ meeting we have the API report which last week posted a headline draw of -7.55mln BPD.

Gold (+0.5%) has reverted back towards the USD 1400/oz level after yesterday’s G20-induced decline; with today’s reversion stemming from a decidedly less-positive market sentiment than yesterday. However, the USD 1400/oz level remains elusive for the yellow metal this morning, for reference session high is currently just over USD 1397/oz. In contrast to yesterday’s gains, copper has remained largely negative throughout the session as risk sentiment turning negative is weighing on the red metal.

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih states that he is 100% confident that a OPEC+ deal for a 9-month extension will be achieved today. (Newswires)

Subsequently, Russia approves the OPEC+ output deal extension for nine-months, and the pact for an extension is to be signed soon., OPEC sources. (Newswires)

Iraq’s oil exports from their Southern ports at 3.39mln BPD for June., according to oil officials. (Newswires)

Elsewhere, Sterling has weakened in response, but still managing to hold 1.2600 vs the Dollar and circa 0.8950 against the Euro.

content:
Auto Names – Demand for new diesel vehicles has significantly fallen around London following the implementation of the London Ultra Low Emission Zone (ULEZ). (FT)

Telecom Names – Nokia’s (NOKIA FH) CEO has stated that European governments are at risk of causing collateral damage on the telecom industry from their attempts to implement new regulations aimed at banning Huawei from 5G networks. (FT)

Fresenius Medical Care (FME GY) – Co’s Kabi has issued a voluntary recall of two lots of Fluorouracil Injection, as there the possibility of glass particulate being present. (Newswires)

Pernod Ricard (RI FP) – Coca Cola Amatil & KKR are reportedly considering a joint bid for the Co’s spirit and wine portfolio. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. are reportedly considering the lowering of their capital buffer in order to fund the ongoing overhaul at the Co.; and are reportedly enquiring as to what the ECB and BAFIN’s position is on having a reduced CET1 ratio. (Newswires)

Accor (AC FP) – Co. partnered with GFH Financial to launch Raffles and Mama Shelter brands in Bahrain. Separately, Covivo have acquired a 32% stake in the Co’s Hotels for USD 176mln. (Newswires)

Banca Intesa – Co. are reportedly to sign a EUR 10bln deal with Prelios regarding UTPs. (Newswires)

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Co. operated around 78k scheduled flights in June, Co’s group June traffic of 14.2mln Pax, +13%. (Newswires)

ABN Amro (ABN NA) – Co. are to team up with Firm24. (Newswires)

Casino (CO FP) – Co. have completed the sale of 3 hypermarkets, 4 supermarkets and a leader price store; for a total of EUR 39mln. (Newswires)

National Grid (NG/ LN) – Co. have published their draft RIIO2 business plans, which are for electricity & gas transmission. (Newswires)

Publicis (PUB FP) – Co. have finalised the acquisition of Epsilon. (Newswires)

L’Oreal (OR FP) – Co. are undertaking discussions to purchase Mugler and Azzaro, anticipated to be completed in 2019. (Newswires)

WPP (WPP LN) – In response to the speculation surrounding Kantar, Co. state that they have entered into exclusive discussions with Bain Capital for the sale of a majority stake in Kantar; with the unit valued at USD 4bln. (Newswires)

Morrisons (MRW LN) – Co. state that IFRS 16 restating will have no impact on business or cash flow; restated 2018/19 profit before tax & exceptionals at GBP 396mln vs. prev. GBP 406mln. (Newswires)

Daily Mail & General (DMGT LN) – Co. state that profitability is predicted to improve as the Co’s ongoing investment programme reaches its peak and revenue growth begins to increase.; Co. remain confident that RMS will generate significant long-term value and is expected to provide modest revenue for 2/3 years. (Newswires)

Investec (INVP LN) - Koseff and Kantor are not going to seek re-election to the Co's board and are to step down from their executive director positions as of 8th August 2019. (Newswires)

Leonardo (LDO IM)/ Thales (HO FP) - Cos are considering the joint acquisition of Maxar Technologies for USD 1bln, according to Leonardo CEO. (Newswires)

subject: Bunds: shallow pull-back from yet another record high
content: The core Eurozone bond and peers have eased back after further advances overnight, with Bunds posting a fresh contract high at 173.39 and the corresponding 10 year cash yield inching closer towards -40 bp before some consolidation and a fade in futures to 173.21 vs Monday’s 137.30 Eurex close. However, the overall tone remains bullish following a stop-fuelled rally through technical levels and little left in terms of major chart resistance ahead of 173.50, 173.79 and then 173.90 that roughly coincides with the aforementioned -0.4% level, matching the current ECB depo rate. Ahead, only Eurozone PPI on the data slate, but ECB’s Knot and Vasiliauskas are scheduled on some calendars.

The Departments for Justice, Business, Culture, International Trade, Work and Pensions, Transport, and Brexit could all be abolished or merged with other departments.

content:

2nd July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as the euphoria from the US-China trade truce began to wane and with the region looking ahead to this week’s key risk events. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was underpinned by strength in mining names and amid a widely anticipated back-to-back rate cut from the RBA, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was choppy and largely reflected the price action in the domestic currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were mixed with the mainland dampened after another liquidity drain by the PBoC, while Hong Kong outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend and amid declines in money market rates, with casino stocks among the biggest gainers following the strong growth in Macau gaming revenue

subject: Spain may conduct vote on forming government on July 23rd
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded indecisive as the euphoria from the US-China trade truce began to wane, Hong Kong played catch-up
  • US Trade Representative Office proposed increased tariffs on EU products due to EU aircraft subsidies, in which it proposed adding more tariffs to USD 4.0bln of EU goods
  • RBA lowered the Cash Rate by 25bps to a record low 1.00% as expected, AUD/USD saw short-lived downside
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Retail Sales, UK Construction PMI, Canadian Manufacturing PMI, OPEC+ Meeting, RBA’s Lowe, Fed’s Williams & Mester, BoE’s Carney, supply from the UK

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as the euphoria from the US-China trade truce began to wane and with the region looking ahead to this week’s key risk events. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was underpinned by strength in mining names and amid a widely anticipated back-to-back rate cut from the RBA, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) was choppy and largely reflected the price action in the domestic currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were mixed with the mainland dampened after another liquidity drain by the PBoC, while Hong Kong outperformed as it played catch up on return from the extended weekend and amid declines in money market rates, with casino stocks among the biggest gainers following the strong growth in Macau gaming revenue. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued by the indecisive risk tone and after mixed results at the 10yr JGB auction failed to spur prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net drain of CNY 90bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8513 (Prev. 6.8716)

US President Trump said a new round of trade talks with China have started and that he expects Chinese President Xi will move on some of the disputed issues. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li reiterated that China will not resort to competitive devaluations and will protect IP rights even more strictly, as well as further ease ownership limits in more sectors. Premier Li added that China will maintain prudent monetary policy and no 'flood-like' stimulus, but will use RRR, targeted RRR and lower real interest rate to help reduce funding costs for small firms. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Hunt said German Chancellor Merkel told him she would look at a new package proposed by a new PM. (Newswires)

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson is considering proposals to reduce the size of the Cabinet after key backers urged him to slim down the government if he becomes PM. The Departments for Justice, Business, Culture, International Trade, Work and Pensions, Transport, and Brexit could all be abolished or merged with other departments. (Telegraph)

US Trade Representative Office proposed increased tariffs on EU products due to EU aircraft subsidies, in which it proposed adding more tariffs to USD 4.0bln of EU goods. (Newswires)

Italy cut its 2019 budget deficit target to 2.04% (Prev. 2.4%), according to a government source. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, DXY was steady around the prior day’s highs after having reigned supreme amongst its G10 counterparts in which EUR/USD slipped below its 200DMA and eventually gave up the 1.1300 handle, while a proposal by the USTR Office to increase tariffs on USD 4.0bln of EU goods due to EU aircraft subsidies, briefly added to the pressure for the single currency. GBP/USD remained dejected following its retreat from 1.2700 and USD/JPY mirrored the indecisive risk tone, while antipodeans were in a holding pattern as attempts by AUD/USD to recoup recent losses were limited ahead of the RBA rate decision in which they cut rates by 25bps as widely expected. The decision immediately saw an initial knee jerk reaction to the downside in AUD/USD, although this was short-lived, and the pair returned to pre-announcement levels as the cut was hardly a surprise considering markets had priced in more than 89% chance for the move.

RBA lowered the Cash Rate by 25bps to a record low 1.00% as expected and stated that it cut rates to support employment growth, as well as provide greater confidence on inflation. RBA noted that the economy can sustain a lower rate of unemployment and that employment growth remains strong, while it added that the outlook for the global economy remains reasonable and that there are signs house prices are stabilizing in Sydney and Melbourne. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures subdued amid the indecisive risk tone and after prices pulled back from USD 60/bbl and subsequently to below USD 59/bbl, despite the agreement by OPEC producers to extend the output cut deal by 9 months. The announcement was no surprise as Russia and Saudi had pre-agreed an extension at the G20, while there was some friction with Iran which opposed the rapid adoption of an OPEC and Non-OPEC cooperation charter. Elsewhere, gold prices saw marginal gains as the USD took a breather overnight and copper was kept subdued amid the lacklustre risk tone.

OPEC agreed to extend the oil output cut by 9 months at current quota levels, which means that the extension must now be approved by Non-OPEC partners including Russia at today’s meeting, while OPEC has also reappointed Secretary General Barkindo for 3 more years. (Newswires)

OPEC source said the closed OPEC meeting was long due to the discussion on the OPEC and Non-OPEC cooperation charter, in which Iran was opposed to the rapid adoption of the charter and a decision should be made in the next meeting. (Twitter)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

US President Trump said he had a great meeting with North Korea Leader Kim and looks forward to meeting him again soon, while he added that their teams will be meeting in the meantime to work out solutions to long-term and persistent problems. In related news, White House National Security adviser Bolton denied media reports the US may settle for a nuclear freeze by North Korea instead of full denuclearization. (Twitter/Newswires)

US President Trump suggested that Iran is playing with fire although he separately commented that hopefully the US will make a deal with Iran and that he would like to exit Afghanistan, but it is a tough position. (Newswires/Fox)

Israel PM Netanyahu said Israel will not allow Iran to develop nuclear weapons. (Newswires)

 

US

Support for FI in early European trade came from a weak Eurozone PMI, which strengthened the Bund (and the T-Note in sympathy). But as the US got to their desks, the complex was sold, though there was brief buying after a mixed ISM report. At settlement, major curve spreads were mixed, but not changing by more than 1bps and US T-note (U9) futures settled 9 ticks lower at 127-22.

US President Trump said Mexico tariffs are off the table and that the country is doing a good job. (Newswires)

subject: RBA says it lowered Cash Rate to support employment growth and provide greater confidence on inflation
content:
Says

  • Economy can sustain lower rate of unemployment.
  • Employment growth remains strong.
  • Outlook for global economy remains reasonable.
  • Central scenario for inflation is to be 2% in 2020.
  • Downside risks from trade disputes affecting investment globally.
  • Signs that house prices are stabilizing in Sydney and Melbourne.

subject: PREVIEW: RBA is expected to deliver a 2nd consecutive rate cut in this month's rate decision due in 30 minutes
content:
RBA will announce its latest rate decision on Tuesday morning in which the central bank is expected to lower the Cash Rate Target for a 2nd consecutive meeting with ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures pricing in 70% expectations of a 25bps rate cut to a fresh record low of 1.00%, although this has dropped from as high as 89% expectations around a week before, while the implied yield curve suggests rates could decline even further to 0.75% as early as November.

This upcoming meeting follows the central bank's decision to lower rates by 25bps as expected last month in what was its first rate adjustment for nearly 3 years, which it said was to support employment growth and provide greater confidence inflation will be consistent with medium-term targets. The board also agreed it was more likely than not that further policy easing would be appropriate and RBA Governor Lowe commented shortly after that it is not unreasonable to expect a lower cash rate from here though the board has not yet made a decision and much depends on the labour market, while he also noted that economic forecast has assumed rates at 1.00% by year-end and that Australia can sustain a jobless rate of “4 point something”. These comments therefore clearly show the RBA is on a downward trajectory on rates as it is already embedded in their economic estimates and considering that the Unemployment Rate remains above the desired levels.

Furthermore, RBA Governor Lowe recently stated that the possibility of lower rates remain on the table and suggested it was practical to expect a further reduction in the Cash Rate as it is unrealistic to think one 25bps cut can alter the growth path. However, Lowe has noted it is important to recognize monetary policy is not the only option and suggested the government can potentially do more for the economy, while he also seemed to question how effective further easing would be globally and suggested that if everyone is easing, the impact on exchange rates is offset.

The data releases since the last meeting have been mixed with Q1 GDP Q/Q softer than expected at 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.2%) and GDP Y/Y inline at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 2.3%). Elsewhere, the latest Employment Change for May has continued to top estimates at 42.3k vs. Exp. 17.5k (Prev. 28.4k) although Unemployment Rate was higher than forecast at 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 5.2%) owing to a surprise increase in the Participation Rate to 66.0% from Prev. 65.8%. This suggests not much progress has been made on jobless numbers which could keep the RBA on track for a back to back rate cut, although the data does correspond to timeframes prior to the June cut and therefore it would be prudent to adopt a wait and see approach to gauge the impact of recent policy easing.

Today’s announcement is set for 0530BST/2330CDT/1230HKT and aside from the rate decision, focus will also be on the tone of the statement for hints on whether market expectations for a total of 3 cuts this year are justified.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed as the trade-truce euphoria begins to wane and with participants looking ahead to upcoming risk events
content:
Asia equity markets trade indecisive as the momentum from the US-China trade truce begins to wane and with the region looking ahead to this week’s key risk events. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 are (Unch.) mixed with Australia underpinned by strength in mining names and amid anticipation the RBA will deliver a back-to-back rate cut in its policy announcement later, while Tokyo trade has been choppy largely reflecting the price action in its currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng and Shanghai Comp. are also varied with mainland China dampened after another liquidity drain by the PBoC, although Hong Kong outperforms as it plays catch up on return from the extended weekend and with gaming stocks among the biggest gainers following the strong growth in Macau gaming revenue.

In FX markets, DXY is steady around the prior day’s highs after having reigned supreme amongst its G10 counterparts in which EUR/USD slipped below its 200DMA and eventually gave up the 1.1300 handle, while a proposal by the USTR Office to increase tariffs on USD 4.0bln of EU goods due to EU aircraft subsidies briefly added to the pressure for the single currency. GBP/USD remains dejected following its retreat from 1.2700 and USD/JPY mirrors the indecisive risk tone, while antipodeans are in a holding pattern as attempts by AUD/USD to recoup recent losses are thwarted ahead of the RBA rate decision in which markets currently price in more than 89% chance for the RBA to cut rates by 25bps. However, not all are convinced with HSBC acknowledging a decent possibility for the RBA to cut rates today but sees August as more likely.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued amid the indecisive risk tone and as participants await the results of a 10yr JGB auction later.
